discussion.content:

The key to the question is the phrase "to overwrite an existing file on the TFTP server". We can only assume that the file is the same name, and if the TFTP server does not allow the file that already exists to be rewriteable then an error ocurrs.

comments.content: When Linux is used changing the folder permission only does not make a difference on files within (except when applying them recursively of course), also on windows you can actually disable inheritance of rights. Anyway, the only solution that always works is allowing the file to be written. So in my understanding it is B. To solve future use cases i would also change the folder rights, but that is actually not the question here.

choices.A: Make the TFTP folder writable by all on the TFTP server.
choices.B: Make the package.conf file writable by all on the TFTP server.
choices.C: Make the package.conf file executable by all on the TFTP server.
choices.D: Make sure to run the TFTP service on the TFTP server.

discussion.content:
We=weight
love=local preference
oranges= originated locally >remotely

pure= eBGP > iBGP learned
refreshment= highest RID.

comments.content: Perfect example :)

What is the reason that the router (this router) still sends traffic that is destined to AS 690 to a neighbor other than 10.222.1.1? Local preference could be one reason. However this router set the weightto 200 for this neighbor. If this router set the weight to any matching prefixes, to higher than 200, for other neighbors, then the answer is D.
But the question is about this router sending packets to another neighbor. Changing the weight on another router will have no impact on this router

Sharing is irrelevant. The question is about what THIS router does. We don't know (or care) if there even are other routers in this AS. On THIS router, we have assigned a weight to one neighbor, and (according to the correct answer) we have assigned a higher weight to a different neighbor.
Local Pref is shared in the same AS

discussion.content: Should be a, as weight values aren't shared between routers, but local preference is, correct?
So where's the another neighbor statement?

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

The AS of the router is 100, the neighbor 10.22.22.1 is AS 1, then the route announce to this must be eBGP route, and it must have a 1 prepend in it. The patten ^690$ shall match any path list that start with 690 and end with 690, so it should not set any weight nor local preference on that.. while local preference does not have effect, the weight should make it prefer to other, but it should not be advertised by other but rather have another setting to set the WEIGHT higher..

show ip bgp regexp ^100$ match the direct peering learned routes from as 100
 ^$ - match locally originated routes
only D makes sense

Not only is the situation described disgustingly, but also regexp will not match prefixes from AS1.
We do not see the settings of "another neighbors".

The question is obviously on the knowledge of path selection, but it is not clear where to apply this knowledge here ...

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is: D
Why does the neighbor have AS1, and we are waiting for updates from AS690?

correct answer is not in options - router is sending traffic elsewhere, because it can never receive update matching as-path statement ^690$ from neighbor in AS 1. So it must receive update from other neighbors and that's why it sends it the other way. But when following "excluding wrong options" approach, D remains the last.
Just D seems to be correct, because LOCAL-PREFERENCE is used for choosing best path between different routers.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct because we are only dealing with one router here, with its different bgp route statements.

Attributes are processed in the order :

1. Prefer the highest weight
2. Prefer the highest local preference

D is ok
I tested in GNS3 and router is choosing weight first between 2 eBGP neighbors for the same route.

Selected Answer: D
weight comes before local-pref in BGP routing decisional process
D is correct

We all know Weight is local to each router, right? So if one of the neighbors has already been set to a weight of 200 (which one has in this config), then the only reason a third neighbor would be used is if weight of a third neighbor was higher.
Because weight is more preferred than Local Pref, it won't matter what you set Local Pref to on any neighbor, the chosen one will always be the weight=200 UNLESS someone else has a higher weight. 
And don't forget, we're only looking at this one router, not a set of routers in an AS.

ip as-path access-list 200 permit ^690$ - prefixes originated in our neighbor AS 690
but neighbor 10.222.1.1 remote-as 1
This route-map will no be in use.

discussion.content: D is the correct Answer

discussion.content: It's funny looking at all of these justifications and wrong answers... The answer is definitely C. If you switch it to "out", it will only send routes to 10.222.1.1 which would fulfill this question lol.

comments.content: I'd like to change my mind. I assumed that neighbor statement is configured on 2nd router. But as I understand now, the another neighbor statement is configured on the same router. If that is the case then indeed answer D is correct.

discussion.content: Weight value in another neighbor statement doesn't matter, because it's local significant value only. So I assume that Weight is the same on both routers and then the only value that matters is Local Preference. That's way A would be correct

discussion.content: disregard my previous comments. correct answer is C. question is why router still send traffic to other neighbor? because route map is set for incoming traffic not for outgoing. if the same configuration is applied with "neighbor 10.222.1.1 route-map SET-WEIGHT out" it should start sending the traffic out to 10.222.1.1.

If take a close look, all options are saying "neighbor statements" not 'neighboring routes', neighboring statements can be ACLs, weight attributes and local preferences. If router has higher weight in another neighbor statement it will prefer the highest weight value.... Cisco is always play with wordings...
The correct answer is D

In the match as-path parameter of the "ip as path " the match string is ^690$ which means than matching AS-PATH variable must start with AS 690, but the neighbour is connected to AS number 1. That's mathing will never happen. Correct me please

Both determine the outbound preference. Weight is matched before the local preference.
D is surely the correct answer.

- Weight : cisco proprietary, local to router, used for outgoing traffic 
- Local Preference : local to AS, used for outgoing traffic
D correct answer
anyone with current 300-410 questions updated onn the 5th of january

Local preference does not determine to what neighbor a router sends traffic. It determines which router in an AS sends the desired traffic. 

Weight can be used to determine which neighbor a router will send traffic to.
I think it's A. D can't be correct as the router has no idea what the weight on his neighbor is.

The question is about routers from local router not neighbors.
So Weight trumps everything and D is correct

discussion.content: Should be a, as weight values aren't shared between routers
The route-map should be applied outbound to send traffic to a particular neighbor.

comments.content: that 10.222.1.1 is a neighbor, the router wants to affect the route propagated by the neighbor, ofc the route map is set inbound...

Yes, the route map is set to affect learned routes, but the learned routes are stored locally, which means when selecting the best route for the local router, the weight is a deciding parameter. Answer D is correct

discussion.content:
I will correct myself, local preference is not locally significant. 

My point still stands, the answer refers to a neighbor statement for weight, not a neighbouring router. So the answer is sound.

Both local preference and weight are locally significant. It is not saying weight is configured on a neighbour, it is saying it is configured on another neighbour statement, ergo another line within the same router increasing the weight value (making it preferred). That is how I am understanding it.
It must be D. Weight will be processed first. If weights are the same THEN it goes to Local Preference.
True, D is making more sense
b is the correct answer
D is correct once weight for Cisco Router is best than Local Preference.

choices.A: The local preference value in another neighbor statement is higher than 250.
choices.D: The weight value in another neighbor statement is higher than 200.
choices.C: The route map is applied in the wrong direction.
choices.B: The local preference value should be set to the same value as the weight in the route map.

discussion.content: For those that say C, when you filter OUT of Area 20 on R2, to which areas are you preventing the updates to enter? That would be Areas 0, 10 which is not what's required here. The correct answer is B, you are filtering INto Area 20 so that updates from Area 0, 5 and Area 10 are not allowed in 20.

Route Filtering:

"in" direction: This would filter routes as they are received by the ABR from another area.
"out" direction: This filters routes as they are advertised out of the ABR to other areas.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Question states that ALL other areas need to have area 5 routes *(including area 10). For this reason, placing the filter outward "OUT" toward area 20 would satisfy the requirement.

"in" direction means it not show up Area 20, and not show up business partner (not get propagated to R2's LSDB) which is not requirement. out direction it shows up Area 20 and not in Business Partner. Answer = B

The only downside to this answer is that it prevents area 20 from learning the prefix.

B is correct answer 

Logic is to pay attention to the option in which area it has asked to apply a filter. If the option was for Area 0 then it should be in the OUT direction i.e. routes going out of Area 0 into another area.

The question has asked to apply a filter in Area 20 which can satisfy condition - inter area routes on the area 5 ABR should be protected from getting into the business partner network, all other areas (area 00 and Area 10) should receive the area 5 internal routes 
R5 is the only router in Area 20 and Area 20 needs to be blocked from receiving routes hence it should be "IN" Direction i.e routes should be blocked entering area 20

https://community.cisco.com/t5/networking-knowledge-base/using-area-lt-gt-filter-llist-command-in-ospf/ta-p/3118832

The question is a bit misleading by saying every area must learn about the route
I believe R2 belongs to us but R5 belongs to the business partner, Area 20 is the area between us and the business partner that we both use to share routes and this is where we control what routes we share with them, by filtering what goes into area 20 on R2

A is just silly trying to filter a route that originates for Area 5 from coming into Area 5

D is the exact thing the Engineer has done which is causing the problem - prevent R1 from advertising the route from area 5 into area 0 which means R2 does not know about it in area 0 to advertise it further to area 10 where it is also needed internally

C is telling R2 not advertise the route from area 20 to any other areas (configured on R2), however, area 20 would need to learn about the route from area 0 first before it can decide whether or not to advertise it out to another area. Best place to apply option C would be on R5 but as mentioned above, I do not believe it is under our jurisdiction

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
"distance eigrp 130 120" set the internal EiGRP routes to 130 and external EIGRP routes to 120. As of the loopback address is advertised in EIGRP as internal route it has an AD of 130. So the RIP route with an AD of 120 is preferred now.

AD 130 for internal
AD 120 for external

now RIP (120) has lower AD than EIGRP

Places internal routes for an AD of 130
Places External routes for AD of 120

A. R1(config)# router rip
R1(config-router)# distance 90
B. R1(config)# router eigrp 1
R1(config-router)# distance eigrp 130 120
C. R1(config)# router rip
R1(config-router)# distance 100
D. R1(config)# router eigrp 1
R1(config-router)# distance eigrp 120 120
Rip has the administrative distance of 120 to make a clear decision we use a higher / worse AD of 130

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. The R2 loopback interface is advertised with RIP and EIGRP using default values. Which configuration changes make R1 reach the R2 loopback using RIP?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Its B. ACL blocks the specific host/port incoming.
You cannot use ACLs to protect the 'management plane' on an interface

comments.content: but option D has no association with SNMP... or is it implicit in the management plane??
In ACL 90 there is no IP that we need to block, so I think the right answer B.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Lets think through this.
A) is wrong because SNMP functions in the management not the control plane.
B) this sounds correct, but if you think about it, it may cause unintended traffic denies. If we create a new ACL to deny the host, the answer does not specify other parameters, and we could assume that a permit any at the end will be configured as well.
C) is wrong, we are trying to block the host.
D) seems to be the best answer. If we use the same ACL 90, we are inherently deny any other hosts that do not require access to R1's management plane, and only permit the ones defined in the ACL.

D is the best answer
B works, but not entirely the best answer.

Selected Answer: B
B is corerct

Selected Answer: B
So , management plane protection(MPP) can be added to an interface. This makes your router only reachable from that interface. But with MPP you can not specify an ACL. So i do not see how D could be correct. Picking B

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/security/configuration/guide/sec_mgmt_plane_prot.html

Selected Answer: B
The ACL would block SNMP packets from reaching the MGMT plane in the first place. 
Option D would also work but would still be processed via the MGMT plane and then be discarded. The less unnecessary packets processed through the MGMT/control plane the better in my opinion.

comments.content: How D is correct?

discussion.content: D is correct

snmp-server community Public RO 90
snmp-server community Private W 90
R1#show access-list 90
Standard IP access list 90
permit 10.11.110.11
permit 10.11.111.12

Console messages are from 10.11.110.12

See the difference between the permit IP statement and host IP?

B is correct.

Selected Answer: D
The question does not specify if the new ACL (answer B) will allow other hosts to access the router through E1/0. I believe the best answer would be D as it uses the existing ACL which block access from the suspected attacker to access R1.

yes, correct option B. Easy question

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network administrator notices these console messages from host 10.11.110.12 originating from interface E1/0. The administrator considers this an unauthorized attempt to access SNMP on R1. Which action prevents the attempts to reach R1 E1/0?

choices.A: Configure IOS control plane protection using ACL 90 on interface E1/0.
choices.C: Add a permit statement including the host 10.11.110.12 into ACL 90.
choices.D: Configure IOS management plane protection using ACL 90 on interface E1/0.
choices.B: Create an inbound ACL on interface E1/0 to deny SNMP from host 10.11.110.12.
